data.title: remove code actions from F8 widget
data.body: Now that we have a better light bulb story we don't need to show code actions in the error zone widget anymore. _after_ _before_

data.title: Remove the error list zone widget
data.body: I would like to remove the error zone widget due to the following reasons: 1. All of this functionality should live in the error list in the panel 2. Looks bad 3. I have a feeling that people are not using this, though for this assumption to be verified I would need @seanmcbreen to check some usage numbers One of the rare features that the zone widget has and that is missing in the error list is captured here #13285 So once we have that and if the usage numbers are not high I propose to remove the error list zone widget. If we decide not to remove it then I volonter to make it look better. @jrieken does not have a strong feeling against removing it Opinions welcome @egamma @chrisdias @sandy081 Picture for reference

data.title: Display multi-line errors in panel list

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: As shown in the picture below we are not displaying multi-line errors in the error list. I would expect that multi-line errors occupy the correct number of lines. I know you are using the tree widget as the underlying implementation, so you can check the repl which does the same. Uses the tree but for elements that are multiple lines it [reserves additional lines](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/replViewer.ts#L119). I am passionate about removing the error zone widget and this is one of the rare things that the error list is missing which the error zone widget provides.

data.title: FileEditorInput leaks and can cause render freezes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: any OS

By just opening and closing editors, `FileEditorInput` objects stay around from `history.ts`. They are lightweight however attach listeners that can result in expensive operations e.g. when files are deleted and they compute if their file resource is impacted by the delete by using `paths.isEqualOrParent`. 

The render freeze is reproducible with the instructions in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12372 after a longer session with files getting opened and closed and running our `gulp watch` command which as a first action deletes all JS files causing many file delete events to happen.

We should investigate to fix this for 1.6.0

data.title: TS definition: ExtensionContext.subscriptions is not defined as array
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.6.0-insider - OS Version: macOS sierra (10.12) Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create an extension 2. In the `activate` function, the `ExtensionContext` parameter has a `subscriptions` property which should be an array (see the definition). The TypeScript definition however declares it as `{}`. This might be quite important. I have no idea when this was introduced. I was looking into upgrading my `vscode-final-newline` extension in the VS Code insiders build. This might be quite important. // @bpasero @jrieken @Tyriar

data.title: [feature] Add a way to tell where a configuration setting exists (user vs workspace)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.6.0-insider (1.6.0-insider)` 782e3ad7e504c308a5f1592ca6ae2574a13b0e73
- OS Version: `macOS Sierra Version 10.12 (16A323)`

Now that there is a way to update configuration settings (at either the workspace or user level), it would be great if there was a way to tell where a configuration setting is currently saved. That way if an extension is trying to update a setting it can do so in the proper location.

Maybe `get` or `has` could have an optional `global` bool like `update` which would only check the global (i.e. user) level?

data.title: Markdown preview does not always refresh
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open new VSCode window
2. Open a project folder
3. Click on README.md
4. Both text and .md preview tabs open
5. Close .md text tab (preview still open)
6. Open another editor window (Sublime)
7. Open the same project folder
8. Open README.md, make changes and save
9. Click on README.md in VSCode Explorer
10. Text tab shows modified content
11. .md preview is now stale
12. Close preview tab so only text tab visible
13. Click on Open Preview icon in upper right
14. .md preview still shows old content
15. Pressing Shift-Cmd-V same thing
16. (Both text and preview tabs still open)
17. Right-click on README.md in Explorer pane and choose Open Preview
18. Focus changes to preview tab, but still stale
19. Close .md preview tab
20. Do step 18 again, and preview shows refreshed content
21. Make more changes in the other editor and save
22. Now it doesn't matter what I do (tried any/all steps above), .md is not refreshing
23. But text tab always refreshes
24. **OK, found a pattern: the .md preview will only reliably refresh if its text tab is open AND in focus** - when making external changes, the text tab auto-updates, and THEN switching to the preview tab shows updated content
25. If .md preview tab is in focus and external change is made, clicking back to the text tab causes a **weird flicker with the focus staying on the preview tab**. Click the text tab again to see updated content, but the refresh problem remains

data.title: Preserves the saved whitespace setting on toggle
data.body:
Associated with #12451

This enhances the `Toggle Render Whitespace` command to utilize the saved configuration setting if there is one that isn't `none`.

data.title: Error running build from source
data.body:
- VSCode Version: code-oss-dev@1.6.0 (source from Oct 4th)
- OS Version: Windows 10 32bits OR 64bits (two different computers - same error)

Steps to Reproduce:
- [X] Following [How to Contribute](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#build-and-run-from-source)
- [X] Install Prerequisites 👍 
  - [X] Node v6.3.1
  - [X] NPM 3.10.8
  - [X] Python 2.7.11
  - [X] Visual Studio 2015 Community with C++
- [X] Install dependencies: `scripts\npm install` 👍 
- [X] Incremental Build: `[23:17:22] Finished compilation with 0 errors after 18584 ms` 👍 
- [ ] Launch development version -> 👎 **Error below**

```
C:\Users\alefr\Documents\GitHub\vscode>scripts\code.bat  --verbose

[93m[main 11:32:15 PM][0m Starting VS Code in verbose mode
[93m[main 11:32:15 PM][0m from: c:\Users\alefr\Documents\GitHub\vscode
[93m[main 11:32:15 PM][0m args: { _: [],
  paths: [],
  performance: false,
  verbose: true,
  debugPluginHost: undefined,

  'new-window': false,
  'reuse-window': false,
  goto: false,
  diff: false,
  extensionHomePath: undefined,
  extensionDevelopmentPath: undefined,
  extensionTestsPath: undefined,
  'disable-extensions': false,
  'open-url': undefined,
  locale: undefined,
  wait: false }
[9704:1005/233219:INFO:CONSOLE(136)] "Loading "gc-signals" failed", source: file:///C:/Users/alefr/Documents/GitHub/vscode/out/vs/loader.js (136)
[9704:1005/233219:INFO:CONSOLE(137)] "Detail: ", source: file:///C:/Users/alefr/Documents/GitHub/vscode/out/vs/loader.js (137)
[9704:1005/233219:INFO:CONSOLE(139)] "Error: Cannot find module '../build/Release/gcsignals'
    at Module._resolveFilename (module.js:455:15)
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (C:\Users\alefr\Documents\GitHub\vscode\.build\electron\resources\electron.asar\common\reset-search-paths.js:35:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:403:25)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
    at Object.<anonymous> (C:\Users\alefr\Documents\GitHub\vscode\node_modules\gc-signals\src\index.js:8:18)
    at Module._compile (module.js:556:32)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:565:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)", source: file:///C:/Users/alefr/Documents/GitHub/vscode/out/vs/loader.js (139)
[9704:1005/233219:INFO:CONSOLE(141)] "Here are the modules that depend on it:", source: file:///C:/Users/alefr/Documents/GitHub/vscode/out/vs/loader.js (141)
[9704:1005/233219:INFO:CONSOLE(142)] "vs/workbench/api/node/mainThreadLanguageFeatures,vs/workbench/api/node/mainThreadHeapService", source: file:///C:/Users/alefr/Documents/GitHub/vscode/out/vs/loader.js (142)
```

The OSS Build runs, but open an empty window. No menu item works, except Help/About, Help/Toggle Developer Tools, File/New Window and File/Close, as you can see in the GIF below.

![build_oss_gcsignals](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3781424/19139176/9b849ed4-8b58-11e6-9e6f-ea4f1caafd33.gif)

Any idea what could be happening? Any missing/invalid pre-requisite? I'm trying to build for about two weeks, and I'm stuck with the same error. I constantly update my sources from GitHub, so it doesn't appears to be a _failed changeset_

Thanks in advance

data.title: Red theme: xml and ascx files are too red.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Win7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open xml file or ascx file or xsl file
2. open html or aspx file
3. switch to Red theme
4. compare open files

(file contents don't matter so long as there is some sort of xml document including tags, attributes and text content; it seems sufficient to save the same file with various extensions)

Expected Results:
- syntactic elements shared between these file types appear the same colors as they do in other themes (Dark theme for example)

Actual Results:
- xml and ascx files do not appear to identify much syntax compared to html or aspx files

data.title: Disable Extension through api
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.x
- OS Version: 10.10.3

Is there a way to disable the extension? Upon disabling the extension we do not want any command traces in the context menu or a command palette. As of now there is a tight coupling with how the commands are declared / registered. 

For our extension we have a need to disable it if a product license or trial version is expired.

Thank you,

Ritesh

data.title: VSCode Extension Issue: Copying file(s) via the scripts fields in the package.json fails.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 7 SP1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Used Yeoman generator to boilerplate a simple VSCode extension. (basically "Hello world")
2. The extension runs great , launches from "DEBUG > Launch Extension" menu as expected.
3. I tried to add a source file (customfunctions.js) to the src directory, but it never gets copied to the output directory when the extension is compiled/launched.

Details:
I've got what seems like it should be a simple thing to do. I want to add a Javascript source file to my "build/compile" process of my VS Code extension. This seems like it should be simple enough, so I added a copy task to the scripts field in the package.json of the extension project. Like so:

```
"scripts": {
    "copy:dist": "cp src/customfunctions.js out/src",
    "vscode:prepublish": "node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/compile",
    "compile": "npm run copy:dist && node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/compile -watch -p ./",
    "postinstall": "node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/install"
},
```

The rest of the VS Code extension project is just a boilerplate VSCode extension generated from a Yeoman generator. I literally just have these files in my extension project src directory :
- the two files boilerplate for the extension-  extension.ts and myDocumentContentProvider.ts
- my custom javascript file customfunctions.js

When I use the 'DEBUG > Launch Extension' mention to test my extension the "Launch Extension" (again boilerplate) has "preLaunchTask": "npm" which I assume runs my package.json and should compile the TS files and (in my case) copy the one js file I've added.

But, for some reason, this doesn't work. My file isn't copied. In fact, the TS files are compiled and the results copied to out/src, but MY custom JS file is not copied.

And, **yes**, I went through all the documentation on extensions (including https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/extension-manifest ), but nothing explains a working way to do this.

data.title: Cannot read property 'uri' of null fix
data.body: There is a case that throw **TypeError: Cannot read property 'uri' of null** when I try to construct and remove the monaco editor in short amount of time in an web app. The **setModelMarkers** is in call stack already while the model is already removed.

data.title: Grouping files by name
data.body:
I really miss the option to group files by name (or couldn't figure out how to do this). Visual Studio has a similar feature (f.e. App.cs has the sub-item App.Designer.cs).

The following examples should clarify this feature request:

Example:
jquery.min.js jquery.min.map will be grouped/hidden to jquery.js

Another example (angular2):
foo.component.ts foo.component.html foo.component.css will be grouped to foo.component

data.title: Dragging in-product release notes to start a new editor group, closes notes and goes to web
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.6.0 insiders
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Follow test plan to enable in product release notes in insiders https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12520
2. Help > Release Notes
3. Try to drag the release notes to the side to start a new editor group.

The release notes editor is closed and the user is directed to the release notes on the website.

This happens when the release notes are in preview mode or as a persistent editor after doing the **Keep Open** command.

This might be related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13105 which has been fixed and included in the October release. Given this is likely a common action for users who want to review the release notes next to another editor group, we may want to fix this for September.

The workaround is to drag the release notes to an existing editor group.

data.title: Zen Mode
data.body:
It would be nice to be able to go into a mode where the current document takes up the entire editor.

This would mean hiding everything except for:
- Menu bar
- Status bar
- Current document

Toggling zen mode could be done like so: <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>alt</kbd> + <kbd>enter</kbd>

And now for some sweet GIMP skills to show how this would look (line numbers could potentially be toggled too):

![vscode-zen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1571806/19124239/0083924c-8af8-11e6-8fac-16f640da8380.png)

As you can see everything is gone. This is helpful especially when you are on a smaller monitor or have multiple editors open.
